bioghist.p: Tomi (Jean-Thomas) Ungerer (b. 1931) is a French illustrator best known for his erotic and political illustrations and for his children's books. Ungerer was born in Strasbourg in Alsace. Ungerer lived through the German occupation of Alsace, during which period his house was requisitioned by the army of Nazi Germany. Ungerer moved to the United States in 1956. The following year, Ungerer published his first children's book for Harper & Row, The Mellops Go Flying. He also did illustration work for the New York Times and for television during this time, and began to create posters denouncing the Vietnam War. After Allumette; A Fable, with Due Respect to Hans Christian Andersen, the Grimm Brothers, and the Honorable Ambrose Bierce was published in 1974, Ungerer spent more than twenty years writing books for adults. In 1998, with the publication of Flix, he made his return to children's literature. Ungerer currently lives in Ireland, where he and his wife moved in 1976. In 1998, Tomi Ungerer was awarded the Hans Christian Andersen Award for illustration. In 2007, the Mus√©e Tomi Ungerer was opened in his honor in Strasbourg.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Tomi Ungerer. Materials include: sketches, illustrations and color separations; mockups, dummies, and proofs; notes, outlines, and drafts of stories; a brief handwritten sketch about the origins of the Mellops; and published volumes. Illustrations are present for a number of Ungerer's books, inlcuding: Crictor, The Mellops Go Flying, The Mellops Go Spelunking, Adelaide, Donkey's Ride, Der Sonntag der Saufamilie Schmutz, and The Three Robbers. Also included are illustrations for Flat Stanley and a Classic Tales Illustrated calendar, 1971.
